### W1 Homework:(2026.02.26) 

#### Estimating the Standard Deviation of OLS estimators in R 

Consider the linear regression model

$$ Y = X\beta + \varepsilon, \varepsilon \sim (0, \sigma^2 I).$$

The variance of the OLS estimator is 

$$ Var (\hat{\beta}_{OLS}) = \sigma^2 (X'X)^{-1}. $$

In practice, we estimate it by 

$$ \widehat{Var} (\hat{\beta}_{OLS}) = \hat{\sigma}^2 (X'X)^{-1} = 
\left(
\begin{array}{ccc}
\hat{b}_{11} & \cdots & \hat{b}_{1p}  \\
& \vdots &  \\
\hat{b}_{p1} & \cdots & \hat{b}_{pp}  \\
\end{array}
\right)_{p\times p}, $$
where 

$$ \hat{\sigma}^2 = \frac{\hat{\varepsilon}'\hat{\varepsilon}}{n-p} , ~~~ \hat{\varepsilon} = Y - \hat{Y}, ~~~ \hat{Y} = X\hat{\beta}_{OLS} $$

The estimated standard deviation of the j-th OLS coefficient $\hat{\beta}_{j,OLS}$ is 

$$ sd(\hat{\beta}_{j,OLS}) = \sqrt{\hat{b}_{jj}}, ~~~j=1,...,p $$

Using R, compute the estimated standard deviations of the OLS estimator in two different ways:

1. Using *lm*

2. Using Matrix Operations

Verify that the two approaches give identical results.
